field_edited_text.value:
xisting Conditions

The many different uses and features
that comprise the network of attractions in
the Inner Harbor today began falling into
place in the late 1970s and early 1980s.

Two major restaurants, apart from
those housed in Harborplace, have located
at the Inner Harbor. The Chart House
opened in 1979 on Pier 4 on the northern
side of the harbor, the first attraction in
that area. Extensive renovation of the old
maintenance shops of the Gas and Electric
Co.’s Power Plant was involved. In 1977,
construction began on the Innef Harbor
marina, the first new major boating facility
to be built in the harbor in years. The
Rusty Scupper opened in 1982 alongside
the city marina on the south edge of the
harbor.

On top of the 30-story World Trade
Center that has become one of the Inner
Harbor’s symbolic structures is The Top of
The World, a public observation deck
opened in 1979. Developed by the Balti-
more Office of Promotion and Fourism, the
observation deck provides the public with
a chance to view the sweep of Baltimore’s
harbor as it spreads from the city center to
the Chesapeake Bay.

Along the western boundary of the
Inner Harbor at Charles Street and Pratt
Street Boulevard are a number of major
buildings completed in the late 1970’s and
early 1980’s. The Baltimore Convention
Center opened in 1979 and provides 115,000
square feet of exhibit and 45,000 square
feet meeting space. Construction was
financed by a $35 million state bond issue
and $10 million in City funds. The Conven-
tion Center tied to the other attractions of
the Inner Harbor, has advanced Baltimore
as a meeting place for many national and
international groups. A major requirement
of the convention market is an adequate
supply of hotel rooms to meet the
demands of the increasing number of vis-
itors. The Hyatt Regency Hotel opened in
1981 with 500 rooms and the potential for
adding 350 more. This luxury hotel is
directly connected to the Convention Cen-
ter and Harborplace by a series of over-
head pedestrian plazas and walkways.

Immediately north of the Convention
Center is the Equitable Center. As the
home office of the Equitable Trust Bank,
the building also contains a shopping mall
and department store branch. A pedestrian
arcade runs through the building, connect-
ing Charles Center with the Convention
Center, the Hyatt, Harborplace and the
promenade.

~In a large triangular piece of land at
the juncture of Light Street and the Pratt
Street Boulevard is the McKeldin Square

and fountain. The fountain is designed to
operate in all but the coldest weather and
replicates waterfalls, pools and rushing
streams. Visitors may walk around and over
the fountain.

The most spectacular singular addition
to the Inner Harbor has been the National
Aquarium in Baltimore, located at the end
of Pier 3.

It’s success is a phenomenon parallel
to that of Harborplace. As the visitor wait-
ing lines attest, the Aquarium has become
a magnet which has exceeded the city’s
original expectations. Instead of a projected
600,000 annual visitors, the facility was
toured by 1.6 million during 1981-82, its
first year. Designed by Peter Chermayeff of
the Cambridge Seven Associates, the aqua-
rium was built by the City of Baltimore for
$21.5 million. The stunning building houses
5,000 specimens of aquatic life and a tropi-
cal rain forest.

As the Inner Harbor project area has
expanded, the City’s attention has been
drawn to the east along the Pratt Street
Boulevard and to Piers 4, 5 and 6 and
across the Jones Falls to Falls Harbor. In
1981 the City erected a concert pavilion on
the end of Pier 6. This large tent structure
can seat over 2000 people under the can-
opy and 400 picnickers outside. Boaters
have room to moor along the side of the
pier. In 1982 canopied pedestrian bridges
linking little Italy and the piers were com-
pleted permitting easy access to harbor
attractions and parking. One of the newest
additions, also completed in 1982, is the
renovated, ornate Eastern Avenue Pumping
Station which houses the Department of
Public Work’s Museum. Adjacent to the
pumping station is a unique sculpture
composed of an above-ground replica of a
street intersection. There, visitors can learn
of the complexities of sewers, gas lines,
storm drains and street construction.

But it is the two Harborplace pavilions,
with their shops, restaurants, and colorful
markets that have captured the public’s
attention. The installation, at a cost of $22
million, has come to be the symbol of the
complete turnaround that has taken place
since 1967 at the Inner Harbor. The indices
of the success of Harborplace are many:
first-year visits totaling 18 million; sales of a
reported $400 per square foot, or more
than twice that in traditional shopping
malls; over 2,000 new jobs; inclusion of the
promised high portion of minority firms
among Harborplace’s 130 shops and restau-
rants, and several millions of dollars paid
each year to the City and State in taxes and
parking revenues.

Now the Inner Harbor promenade,
almost a mile and a half long, functions like
a boardwalk tying together attractions,

businesses and the many special events
along the waterfront.



lssues and Problems

Along with the overwhelming success
of the Inner Harbor there are several issues
to be addressed. Heading the list continue
to be two problems which have confronted
Baltimore for at least 30 years, namely traf-
fic and parking. Pratt and Lombard Streets
along the north side of the Inner Harbor
are two of the city’s major traffic arteries.
Improvements to the existing street system

* and the new 1-95 Fort McHenry harbor

tunnel, will draw off some of the through
traffic, especially heavy trucks, but there is
every likelihood that Pratt, Lombard and
Light Streets will continue to carry heavy
traffic. The City has addressed this problem
through the use of innovative traffic con-
trol devices, traffic police to direct vehicles
and pedestrians at critical intersections dur-
ing peak hours, and by promoting the
development of overhead walkways allow-
ing visitors to reach the harbor without
conflicts with traffic. There is a widespread
public perception that parking is inade-
quate in the Inner Harbor. While there are
over 5,000 spaces open to the public within
several blocks of the promenade, many
people claim that it is difficult to find a
parking place. The actual fact is that at
nearly all times, there are hundreds of
unused parking places within several blocks
of the Harbor. The public is not always
aware of those spaces, however. The City is
addressing this issue by extensive signing of
parking garages and provision of maps
showing where parking is available. In addi-
tion, the City has plans for adding new







86

SRR B

Boating in the Inner Harbor
